Dick Cheney, former US vice president and 'father' of the Iraq invasion, has died
subhead: During President George W. Bush's two terms, Cheney, a foreign policy hawk who was deeply influenced by conservative ideas, embodied the excesses of the war on terror. He died at the age of 84, his family announced on November 4.

title: For France's prime minister, a budget 'endurance race'
Cement maker Lafarge goes on trial in France for 'funding terrorism' in Syria
subhead: The company and eight former employees are standing trial for having paid money to jihadist groups to keep a plant in Syria running. Unusually, Lafarge had already pleaded guilty to this charge before US courts in 2022.

title: Shein says will cooperate with France in sex doll probe
subhead: The Paris prosecutors' office launched investigations after France's anti-fraud unit reported that Shein was selling childlike sex dolls. On Monday, Shein announced it was imposing a 'total ban on sex-doll-type products' and had deleted all listings and images linked to them.

title: Rosalía returns with mystical album: 'God has given me so much, the least I could do is make an album for him'
subhead: Three albums and a string of hit singles have propelled her to the ranks of global pop divas. After a three-year hiatus, the 33-year-old Catalan artist returns with 'Lux,' a musical fresco in praise of the divine and major female saints.

title: How New York became a nightmare for Airbnb
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (6/6). For the past two years, short-term tourist rentals have effectively been banned in the American metropolis as the result of a massively complex regulatory overhaul. The platform is now hoping, without much optimism, to see the rules eased after the municipal elections on Tuesday.
byline: By Nicolas Chapuis (New York (United States) correspondent)

Svalbard, the fastest-warming place on Earth
subhead: 'Our planet at +1.5°C' (1/6). The Norwegian archipelago has warmed by 4°C over the past 30 years. Landslides and thawing permafrost threaten the population, whose way of life is highly greenhouse gas-intensive.
byline: By Audrey Garric (Longyearbyen (Norway) special correspondent) and Adrienne Surprenant

title: The French cities utterly transformed by Airbnb
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (3/6). Turning an apartment into short-term tourist accommodation may seem harmless. But on a large scale, it ends up transforming entire cities and daily life for their residents. France's politicians are trying to crack down on the system.
byline: By Véronique Chocron and Jessica Gourdon

title: China uses subsidies, coercion and propaganda to boost falling birth rates
subhead: After zealously enforcing the one-child policy, the city of Tianmen has made boosting the birth rate a top priority, as fertility continues to decline across China.
